facts.text: Appellants constitute a partnership engaged in mining business and held a prospecting licence in Madhya Pradesh with concessions for prospecting and working minerals in several areas.
Under Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948 and Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, prospecting licence or mining lease requires certificate of approval from State Government.
Appellants obtained certificate of approval from Government of Madhya Pradesh from 1952, renewed yearly up to December 31, 1955.

Appellants applied on November 22, 1955 to Government of Madhya Pradesh for renewal of certificate for 1956, furnished required information, filed documents, recommended by District Officer, Bhandara.
Government of Madhya Pradesh rejected application on September 21, 1956 (communicated October 6, 1956) on ground that partners composing the firm had changed.
Appellants applied on November 15, 1956 to Union Government for review under Rule 57 of Mineral Concession Rules, 1949.

Correspondence ensued between Central Government and Government of Madhya Pradesh regarding the review application; appellants requested information, progress update, and personal hearing but were not informed of State Government's report or documents prior to rejection order.
Union Government rejected review application on July 9, 1958, stating no valid ground for interfering with State Government's decision; based on State report not disclosed to appellants.
Appellants requested copy of State Government's report but were refused.
Appellants filed petition under Article 226 to Punjab High Court for writ of certiorari to quash Union Government's order; dismissed in limine on September 24, 1958.
Civil Appeal No. 115 by special leave under Article 136 against Union Government's order dated July 9, 1958; Civil Appeal No. 116 against High Court order.
Appellants' case: Partnership deed provides for continuance of firm identity notwithstanding changes in partners by death, retirement, or accession of new members.
State Government refused renewal considering change in composition of firm destroyed its identity.

legal_issues.text: Whether Union Government under Rules 57 and 59 of Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 acts as quasi-judicial authority and whether its order rejecting review without disclosing State Government report and without affording hearing to appellants violates natural justice.
Whether Punjab High Court erred in holding jurisdiction under Rules 57 and 59 as administrative rather than quasi-judicial.

petitioner_arguments.text: Union Government disposing application under Rule 57 in terms of Rule 59 acts as quasi-judicial authority; order passed considering State report without disclosing contents or affording opportunity to present case is contrary to natural justice and void.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India; principles of natural justice

respondent_arguments.text: Counsel for respondent-Union of India did not support refusal to disclose contents of State report.

court_reasoning.text: Union Government under Rule 59 functions as quasi-judicial authority; cannot act on material (State report) without giving appellants opportunity to make representation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Same principle applies whether review granted or rejected based on undisclosed materials.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants entitled to know points in State report against their representations and opportunity to rebut; non-disclosure violates natural justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasonable opportunity of being heard is sine qua non of fair hearing.

court_reasoning.text: Punjab High Court erred viewing jurisdiction as administrative; Supreme Court had reversed similar view in Shivji Nathubhai post High Court judgment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court lacked advantage of Supreme Court pronouncement.

holdings.text: Order of Central Government dated July 9, 1958 vitiated as contrary to principles of natural justice for lack of reasonable opportunity to be heard.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports that Central Government under Rule 59 acts quasi-judicially; principle applies to rejection of review based on undisclosed materials.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs scheme requiring certificate of approval for prospecting licence or mining lease.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Rule 57 allows application to Central Government for review of State refusal; Rule 59 provides procedure where Central Government acts quasi-judicially.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave for appeals; writ petition to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds Union Government's order dated July 9, 1958 rejecting review vitiated by violation of natural justice; both appeals challenge same order and are dealt together.
outcome.relief_granted: Order declared void as contrary to natural justice.

key_quotes.text: the Central Government acting under the rule referred to is functioning as a quasi-judicial authority. It does follow therefore that they could not act on the basis of material as regards which the appellants had no opportunity to make their representation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes quasi-judicial nature and natural justice requirement.

key_quotes.text: reasonable opportunity of being heard which is a sine qua non of a fair hearing.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on violation of natural justice.
